Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Advancing Space Science through Undergraduate Research Experience (ASSURE) at University of California (UC) Berkeley
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Space Sciences Laboratory at UC Berkeley seeks to increase the number of minority students in STEM careers through the establishment an NSF REU site to serve first-generation students from Minority Serving Institutions, in particular Community Colleges. The Advancing Space Science through Undergraduate Research Experiences (ASSURE) program will provide authentic research opportunities for first-generation students with limited or no access to STEM research opportunities. Students will work in a multi-tiered mentoring environment, with research mentors, coordinator mentors and peer mentors to conduct cutting edge research in the areas of space science and engineering. Topics students will explore research on include solar physics, planetary science, cosmochemistry, astronomy, space-instrument design and manufacturing, instrument calibration and orbital dynamics.

The National Research Council?s decadal survey of solar and space physics raised concerns about the number of scientists in this field of research. Declining enrollments in relevant departments have led to a reduction in the availability of courses in solar and space physics which threatens the pipeline of future researchers in this field. This REU Site will serve as a mechanism to encourage careers in solar and space physics, particularly among minority students. Student participants will spend 10 weeks at SSL at UC-Berkeley where they will be provided research, leadership and role-modelling opportunities. The students will gain professional role-models at SSL, and they themselves will become role models for the next generation of students by conducting outreach after their summer experiences. SSL is suited to provide a unique REU experience, as SSL has the capacity to design, build, test, communicate with, and analyze data from satellites. Participants will have continued mentoring after the summer program, and will be able to present their research results at the American Geophysical Union meeting. The PI leading this program has been trained in, and has experience in the area of culturally sensitive science education and outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a Research for the Education of Undergraduates (REU) project at the Space Sciences Laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley. The project aimed to train undergraduate students in science and engineering via summer research experiences in space science. It was designed to recruit and retain students who may not otherwise have access to research opportunities (known as under-served students.) The project also set out to prepare and support space scientists in mentoring undergraduate research students, and in particular under-served students.  

 

Intellectual Merit

This project was evaluated by a professional evaluator. Professional evaluators are trained to impartially interview and conduct surveys of participants in science and engineering education efforts. Based on the evaluation of this REU project at the Space Sciences Laboratory at UC Berkeley, the project was extremely successful in meeting its goals. Out of 534 applicants, 28 students took part in a summer internship either in 2015, 2016, or 2017. All of the students who participated in the project met at least one of the following criteria: being the first in their family to attend college, economically disadvantaged, coming from a community college, or coming from a small 4-year college where research opportunities were not available.

During the summer internship, the undergraduate students learned what space science research is in laboratories. Students learned computer programming, space physics concepts, and methodologies for answering research questions. Students were also trained on and practiced communication skills (e.g. professional emails, elevator speeches, poster presentations, seminar presentations). The students who participated all indicated that the REU project was effective in developing students` understanding of research, careers, academic preparation, and skills. All of the students reported that the experience was valuable. The project processes and support were effective for the mentors and the students, with both reporting they would recommend it to others.

This project attracted new and upcoming talent to the field of space science by increasing awareness and appeal across a diverse population of students. The learning curve for under-served students can be steeper than from those already attending university given the differences in institutional practices, the level of independent working, and the intensity of coursework. However, we have shown that with sufficient preparation and support throughout their experiences, community college students can succeed in research environments.

In meeting its goals, the project provided new insight into creating successful REU summer internships. Specifically, the project demonstrated that creating a week-long ``boot camp`` for students in the first week of the internship was highly effective at preparing under-served students for the summer research activities. At the boot camp, the selected undergraduate students heard talks about the research from potential mentors, students learned programming skills in python and IDL, mentors and students interacted, students participated in activities that oriented them to the culture and layout of the laboratory, and students and mentors went through a ``speed matching`` activity. At the end of the week, project leads determined the best mentor-student match based on student skills and student or mentor interests.

This project also discovered that accepting a mix of computer science, science, and engineering majors was imperative for the success of the research and satisfaction of the students and mentors. This is because different research projects require different skills, so students were better able succeed in their research projects more quickly. Additionally, the team discovered that pairing two students with different strengths with a single mentor also provided better research and happier/more motivated students and mentors. Innovations by mentors included Friday briefings on the content related to the next week`s tasks and giving their two interns the same task to work on independently, then collaborate.

 

Broader Impacts

This project provided professional development for the Research Scientists and Engineers acting as mentors to the undergraduates. This professional development included providing information on the demographics of the students coming to the project and some awareness building of hidden biases. Mentors participating in the project became aware of their style of communication and interaction, which was shown to be a valuable factor in how welcome the interns felt in a research laboratory setting. In addition, participating mentors indicated that they became more conscientious about their teaching/instructing style.

This project has increased under-represented student`s confidence in their own ability. One intern who had previously held a job working graveyard shifts at a fast food restaurant told one of the project leads that his research as an intern at the Space Sciences Laboratory gave him the confidence to apply for a position as an electrical engineer and resign from his fast food position. He attribute his time in the project to having the self-belief that he could ``actually do this for real and not just on paper.``
